Pwnd: Oh, thanks. But I, to be honest, prefer making it all by hand. I am using something called "Jehu", a Java editor made by a friend of the teacher I had a few years ago in programming in the Java course. The program is all in Swedish, so nothing I really recommend if you don't know any Swedish. Smiley
Well, I mean, you can import the GUI (iirc), and then make changes.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

On another topic

Yes that is true. But the contact list might have been just half loaded. If it is just half loaded, how would the client recognize it isn’t fully loaded? Maybe one thing could be to store a file containing all the information on who is making that contact list to be fully loaded, on the clients computer. But in that case it could be changed client-side. You could add whoever you want to that list, and see if they are logged in or what not.

What you could do, is save the updated contact list to a file whenever it’s updated(this would be the control), and the current list to a temp file, and check the md5 sum of each files. That way you do two things at once, have important backups of the contact list and check to see if it was loaded properly. (I assume the client doesn’t download the user’s whole contact list from a server?)

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

On another topic

That since, what I can remember, is one of the most common mistakes people make in English.

Yes, ‘its’ refers to the possessive form, and ‘it’s’ is the form of being.

Its: It has ownership of
It’s: It is.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @dragonus18 dragonus18
item.description:
@dragonus18 wrote:

[quote=“Protosstribe, post:1, topic:152132”]Pwnd: Oh, thanks. But I, to be honest, prefer making it all by hand. I am using something called “Jehu”, a Java editor made by a friend of the teacher I had a few years ago in programming in the Java course. The program is all in Swedish, so nothing I really recommend if you don’t know any Swedish.

By the way, just to clearify one thing about my English skills… Shouldn’t it be “its” instead of “it’s” in the message you wrote? As far as I am concerned, “it’s” is referring to a statement, and “its” is referring to an actual object that is inheriting another object (in real life).[/quote]
pwnd is asian and allowwed to make grammar mistakes, but all in all you are right.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

But without a handshake and the sequence numbers, spoofing on UDP is a lot easier. If used incorrectly, it can allow certain DoS (fill up a contact list) and DDoS (if authentication relies on a “connect to me”-packet) attacks to be performed.
These are things to consider

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Actually TCP has quite a bit more overhead, it has to keep track of the sequence number of the packet for one, and all of the queueing, waiting and resending takes a toll too. As to ‘today’s internet speeds’ It is still a huge problem, perhaps more than it ever was in the past, most networks are having problems keeping up with the massive growth of the internet.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

UDP is usually not used for anything that requires definite assurance of packets to be transmitted. TCP doesn’t have much more overhead than UDP, and anyway, with today’s internet speeds TCP is perfectly fine.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:11, topic:151888”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=207796.msg1825131#msg1825131 date=1192517903]

Also are you using UDP or TCP?

UDP is gay.

UDP does not guarantee reliability or ordering in the way that TCP does. Datagrams may arrive out of order, appear duplicated, or go missing without notice. Avoiding the overhead of checking whether every packet actually arrived makes UDP faster and more efficient, at least for applications that do not need guaranteed delivery.

I think a messenger would be pretty unreliable if it used UDP.

Haha, good job looking up a wikipedia article. UDP has its advantages, such as being much faster and having less overhead than TCP, and you can implement your own error checking if you have a need or wish to. Also wikipedia should have told you that both UDP and TCP travel over the lower-level IP protocol, deep down they are the same
[/quote]

What if we’re lazy and don’t want to implement our own error checking protocol? ;)[/quote]then suffer the consequences…

Read full topic

UDP is gay.

UDP does not guarantee reliability or ordering in the way that TCP does. Datagrams may arrive out of order, appear duplicated, or go missing without notice. item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:6, topic:151888”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=207796.msg1824744#msg1824744 date=1192506115]
Also are you using UDP or TCP?
[/quote]

UDP is gay.

UDP does not guarantee reliability or ordering in the way that TCP does. Datagrams may arrive out of order, appear duplicated, or go missing without notice. Avoiding the overhead of checking whether every packet actually arrived makes UDP faster and more efficient, at least for applications that do not need guaranteed delivery.

I think a messenger would be pretty unreliable if it used UDP.[/quote]

Both work, and UDP is not unreliable… And it’s not bad! UDP is User Datagram Protocol; It’s great for quick, low overhead… It’s even bette for first person shooters; due to the fact it wont backup and cause “lag” because some routing server buffered a few too many packets and couldn’t send it out… instead it chalks it up to loss and we receive the most up to date (newest) packet on time; allowing for much better and efficient hit collision.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The hybrid version would substantially lower the load on your server, but it might be slightly more complicated. Also are you using UDP or TCP?

And since it looks like you are using Java, it should be very easy to keep it cross-platform, as long as you aren’t an idiot like some of my professors and use “\” as a file separator (using “/” is platform independant), or assume that all file systems are not case-sensitive.

Read full topic

item.title: [Can be removed]
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It looks very nice, just be careful to keep it cross-platform and it should be a huge hit.

Are you developing this with a client-server or peer-to-peer architecture? Or perhaps a hybrid combination of both? (ie, client connects to server to see what peers are on and what their IP is, and then connects directly to the peer for chat)

Read full topic
